results.title: Finding Forrester [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Rhonda Tollefson, Sean Connery, Laurence Mark, Fountainbridge Films, Laurence Mark Productions and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Basketball star and ‘C’ student Jamal Wallace (Rob Brown) surprises everyone except himself when his amazing writing abilities and basketball prowess attract the attention of a Manhattan private school. Outside his old school in the Bronx lives a reclusive old man (Sean Connery) who Jamal meets when, on a dare from his friends, enters the building and is frightened when he encounters the man the students call, “The Window”. In his haste to escape he leaves behind his backpack, only to have it returned the following day with comments written in his personal writing notebooks. Jamal returns to the apartment and slowly wins the trust of the old man who convinces him to attend the new school and learn all he can about himself. Inspired by his new mentor, he agrees, and it is at this school that he discovers that the short-tempered old man who has been helping him improve his writing is actually Pulitzer prize winning author William Forrester, a man famous for only ever writing one book. Cast also includes F. Murray Abraham, Anna Paquin, Busta Rhymes and a special cameo appearance by Matt Damon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gus Van Sant, Rhonda Tollefson, Sean Connery, Laurence Mark, Fountainbridge Films, Laurence Mark Productions and Columbia Pictures

results.title: A Soldier's story [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Patrick Palmer, Ronald L Schwary, Columbia Pictures and Caldix Films
results.brief_description: Director Norman Jewison explores themes in “A Soldier’s story” similar to his Academy Award-winning “In the Heat of the Night”. It is World War II and an all black platoon at a Georgia army base spends its time finessing their baseball skills while awaiting the go-ahead to join the war effort. They’re led by the sadistic, incendiary Sergeant Vernon Waters, who rules the platoon with an iron fist and shouts harsh, racist comments even though he himself is an African-American. “A Soldier’s story” begins with the mysterious murder of Waters and then traces the investigation of the crime by black officer, Captain Davenport. Though Davenport suspects two white soldiers of killing Waters, his instincts are proven wrong and the real killer is a dramatic and moving surprise. “A Soldier’s story” is a well-crafted drama that raises the important issue of race relations in America and how racism and discrimination find their way in such official institutions as the military. In fact, the film shows how the military’s power structure supports the abuse of power and iron force rule. Its message overall is bleak: in this microcosmic world of the army, racial discrimination has led to a split in the notion of brotherhood among black men in America with Sergeant Waters internalising and projecting racial conflict on his blood brothers. Cast includes Howard E. Rollins Jr., Adolph Caesar, Art Evans, Denzel Washington and Wings Hauser. Music score by Herbie Hancock.

results.title: Beautiful people [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jasmin Disdar, Ben Woolford and Beautiful stories
results.brief_description: The ethnic conflict in the former Yugoslavia is an unlikely subject matter for this British black comedy which uses the Balkan war as a catalyst to explore a contemporary London bursting with racial discord. The films interconnected stories are set off by a brawl between a Serbian (Dado Jehan) and a Croatian (Faruk Pruti) on a busy downtown London bus, an apt and humorous metaphor for the worsening situation. Meanwhile a headmaster’s football hooligan son, inadvertently lands right in the middle of the war, a Tory MP’s daughter (Charlotte Coleman) falls in love with one of her patients and a BBC war correspondent suffering from ‘Bosnia syndrome’ tries to amputate his leg. Cast also includes Charles Kay, Julian Firth, Edward Jewsebury, Edin Dzandzanovic, Gilbert Martin. (Award: 1999 Winner-Un Certain Regard, Jasmin Disdar)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jasmin Disdar, Ben Woolford and Beautiful stories

results.title: All over me
results.creator_credit: Alex Sichel, Dolly Hall, Baldini Pictures, Slam Pictures and Medusa Pictures
results.brief_description: Fifteen year old Claude (Alison Folland) works part time in a pizza shop, lives with her mother in a small apartment in Hell’s Kitchen and loves to jam with her best friend Ellen (Tara Subcoff). However, Claude’s world is starting to change; Claude realises that she has developed stronger feelings for Ellen. Ellen is spending less time with Claude because she has a new boyfriend, Mark, whose aggression and homophobia alienate Claude. Luke (Pat Briggs), a gay musician, has moved into her apartment block and encourages Claude’s interest in music and the world she lives in. When Claude meets Lucy (Leisha Hailey from The Murmers), her recognition of her homosexuality comes to the fore. However, Claude’s world and the people in it are careering out of control; violence abounds and Claude witnesses Ellen’s increasingly complex relationship with drugs. The Sichel sisters, Alex (director) and Sylvia (writer) have created a rites-of-passage film about coming out and growing up in the unforgiving environment of Hell’s Kitchen. The desultory mood of the film and the subtle performance of Folland as Claude launches a dramatic debut feature for the Sichel sisters. (Awards: Winner, Gay Teddy bear at the 1997 Berlin Film Festival)

results.title: The Wind Will Carry Us
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Marin Karmitz and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: Behzad Dourami plays an engineer who arrives with a film crew in an isolated Iranian village high in the mountains. It is not made clear why the men from the city have arrived in the village, except that they seem very interested in the illness and death throes of an old woman. A young boy escorts the men around his home and the engineer becomes familiar with both the landscape and personages of this small rural community. Kiarostami’s films utilise realist conventions - non-actors, real sound and location - to create highly personal and philosophical works that examine the broad existential and theological questions of human life. Whereas the urban men at the beginning of the film are cynical and disparaging of the traditional lifestyle and values of the villagers, what the engineer discovers is that the timeless ethical codes of the village are well suited to dealing with the fundamental issues of life and death. He also discovers that beneath the veneer of stability and order in the village, chaos and change also have their place. Enriched by Mahaoud Kalar’s ravishing cinematography, “The Wind Will Carry Us” is an important addition to Kiarostami’s oeuvre as one of the foremost spiritual and philosophical of contemporary directors. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1999 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: Twin Peaks: fire walk with me
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Gregg Fienberg and Twin Peaks Productions
results.brief_description: David Lynch’s prequel to the cult television series, “Twin Peaks”, depicts the last seven days in the life of Laura Palmer, whose plastic-wrapped corpse was found floating in the river in the introduction of the TV series. In the quiet town of Twin Peaks, Laura is the popular prom queen by day. By night, however, she is the sex-crazed cokehead who prostitutes herself to support her drug habit. Her race to oblivion is escalated further by an awareness of sexual abuse which has been taking place since she was a child. Cast includes: Sheryl Lee, Ray Wise, Moira Kelly, Harry Dean Stanton, Kyle MacLachlan, Kiefer Sutherland, James Marshall, Grace Zabriskie, Pam Gidley, David Lynch, David Bowie and Chris Isaak.

results.title: Hostage
results.creator_credit: Robert Young, Tom Kinnimont, Jorge Estrada Mora Producciones, Tyne Tees Television, Independent Image and Portman Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: Based on the novel “No place to hide” by Ted Allbeury, “Hostage” is about a man on the run, a man who wants nothing more to do with the life of a British Secret Service Agent. A professional killer who murders in the name of Queen and country, John Rennie (Sam Neill) has one more job to do. A senior defence analyst is taken hostage by terrorists and it is up to Rennie to secure the release of the hostage and eliminate the terrorists. This leads him to Argentina, to secrecy and corruption, violence and seduction and eventually to the fatal mistake of falling in love. Plans start to fall apart, doubts begin to set in and Rennie’s questioning of his orders make him a liability - a danger to National Security. Cast also includes Talisa Soto, James Fox, Art Malik, Cristina Higueras, Michael Kitchen, Jean Pierre Reguerraz.

results.title: Gangster no. 1
results.creator_credit: Paul McGuigan, Jonathan Cavendish, Norma Heyman, Pagoda Productions and FilmFour
results.brief_description: Told mainly in flashback, “Gangster No.1” chronicles the bloody rise and unceremonious fall of the oddly named Gangster 55 (Malcolm McDowell/Paul Bettany). Director Paul McGuigan’s violent fable follows the young Gangster’s initiation into London’s glamourous crime scene of the sixties, after he is hand picked by the suave and sinister crime boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis). Gangster’s violent disposition quickly escalates him to the inner circle of Freddie’s crime syndicate, while the impressionable Gangster begins to develop a strong infatuation for Freddie and his opulent lifestyle. The obsession takes a dangerous turn however when Freddie meets night club singer Karen (Saffron Burrows), leaving the jealous Gangster fuming and thirsty for revenge. McGuigan’s flashy visual style fetishizes this motley crew of gangsters, at times filming them in slow motion, bathing them in lush colours and filtering their violence through fractured lenses. Cast includes Kenneth Cranham, Jamie Foreman and Eddie Marsan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul McGuigan, Jonathan Cavendish, Norma Heyman, Pagoda Productions and FilmFour

Cast includes Kenneth Cranham, Jamie Foreman and Eddie Marsan.
description_for_label: Told mainly in flashback, “Gangster No.1” chronicles the bloody rise and unceremonious fall of the oddly named Gangster 55 (Malcolm McDowell/Paul Bettany). Director Paul McGuigan’s violent fable follows the young Gangster’s initiation into London’s glamourous crime scene of the sixties, after he is hand picked by the suave and sinister crime boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis). Gangster’s violent disposition quickly escalates him to the inner circle of Freddie’s crime syndicate, while the impressionable Gangster begins to develop a strong infatuation for Freddie and his opulent lifestyle. The obsession takes a dangerous turn however when Freddie meets night club singer Karen (Saffron Burrows), leaving the jealous Gangster fuming and thirsty for revenge. McGuigan’s flashy visual style fetishizes this motley crew of gangsters, at times filming them in slow motion, bathing them in lush colours and filtering their violence through fractured lenses. Cast includes Kenneth Cranham, Jamie Foreman and Eddie Marsan.

results.title: Julien Donkey-boy
results.creator_credit: Harmony Korine, Cary Woods, Robin O'hara, Scott Macaulay and Independent Pictures
results.brief_description: The first American entry to Dogma 95 is the second feature for Harmony Korine who faithfully embraces the manifesto by improvising scenes, shooting digitally, only using available light and minimal post-sound. “Julien Donkey-boy” also utilizes the loose narrative (or non-narrative) structure of his controversial feature debut “Gummo” (1997), offering a series of randomly connected vignettes in the life of an ‘average’ American family. Ewen Bremner plays the title character, a child-like schizophrenic whom we first see as he murders a young boy, then promptly goes home and forgets about it. Korine serves up an uncomfortable portrait of family life for Julien: a dictatorial father who is prone to wearing a gas mask (played with glee by director Werner Herzog), his sister, Pearl (Chloe Sevigny), who is pregnant with Julien’s baby and a young wrestling obsessed brother (Evan Neumann) whose father pays him to dress up in his dead mother’s clothes. The films loose style and roving camera makes it feel uncomfortably documentary like at times, while the films grainy, ‘no-frills’ look produces some surprisingly haunting and beautiful images. Cast also includes Joyce Korine and Chrissy Kobylak.
